title: Kristijan Bistrović
text:
Kristijan Bistrović (; born 9 April 1998) is a <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>n <a href="association%20football">football</a> player who plays as a <a href="defensive%20midfielder">defensive midfielder</a> or <a href="central%20midfielder">central midfielder</a> for <a href="S%C3%BCper%20Lig">Süper Lig</a> club <a href="Fatih%20Karag%C3%BCmr%C3%BCk%20S.K.">Fatih Karagümrük</a>, on loan from <a href="Russian%20Premier%20League">Russian Premier League</a> club <a href="PFC%20CSKA%20Moscow">CSKA Moscow</a>.
Club career.
Slaven Belupo.
Bistrović made his senior debut for <a href="NK%20Slaven%20Belupo">Slaven Belupo</a> on 30 May 2015, coming on for <a href="Petar%20Mi%C5%A1i%C4%87">Petar Mišić</a> in 77th minute as Slaven lost 3–2 to <a href="NK%20Osijek">Osijek</a>. His proper debut came during <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Croatian%20First%20Football%20League">2016–17 season</a> after the winter break, when he joined the senior team permanently. In summer 2017, during the preseason, Slaven drew 1–1 with <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20Russian%20Premier%20League">Russian champions</a> <a href="FC%20Spartak%20Moscow">Spartak Moscow</a> in a friendly match in <a href="Villach">Villach</a> on 7 July. Slaven's equalizer was a joint effort of Bistrović and <a href="Bruno%20Bogojevi%C4%87">Bruno Bogojević</a>, who netted it in. The match helped Bistrović attract attention of the Russian market, with Spartak's <a href="Main%20Moscow%20derby">rivals</a> <a href="PFC%20CSKA%20Moscow">CSKA Moscow</a>'s coach <a href="Viktor%20Goncharenko">Viktor Goncharenko</a> insisting that the club buys the young Croatian.
CSKA Moscow.
On 12 January 2018, CSKA Moscow signed Bistrović for <a href="Euro">€</a>500,000 until the summer of 2022. At the time of signing for the Moscow club, Bistrović had made only sixteen appearances for Slaven. On 8 March, he made his debut for the team in the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">UEFA Europa League</a> <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Round%20of%2016">round of 16</a> match against <a href="Olympique%20Lyonnais">Lyon</a> where he came on as a substitute for <a href="Alan%20Dzagoev">Alan Dzagoev</a> in the 82nd minute. In the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Quarter-finals">quarter-final</a> home leg against <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> on 12 April, he was praised for his performance as CSKA drew 2–2, but nevertheless failed to progress to the <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20knockout%20phase%23Semi-finals">semi-finals</a>.
On 27 July, he played the whole game in the <a href="2018%20Russian%20Super%20Cup">2018 Russian Super Cup</a> as CSKA defeated <a href="FC%20Lokomotiv%20Moscow">Lokomotiv Moscow</a> 1–0 after <a href="Overtime%20%28sports%29">extra time</a>, earning Bistrović his first career trophy. He scored his first goal for CSKA on 18 August to contribute to a 3–0 victory over <a href="FC%20Arsenal%20Tula">Arsenal Tula</a>. On 1 September, he scored and assisted in a 4–0 victory over <a href="FC%20Ural%20Yekaterinburg">Ural Yekaterinburg</a>, but suffered an ankle injury in closing minutes of the game. He came back to the team as an injury time substitute for <a href="Arn%C3%B3r%20Sigur%C3%B0sson">Arnór Sigurðsson</a> in a 2–0 victory over <a href="FC%20Zenit%20Saint%20Petersburg">Zenit Saint Petersburg</a> on 11 November. Sixteen days later, he made his <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">Champions League</a> debut in a 2–1 defeat to <a href="FC%20Viktoria%20Plze%C5%88">Viktoria Plzeň</a>.
On 24 November 2019, he provided his compatriot <a href="Nikola%20Vla%C5%A1i%C4%87">Nikola Vlašić</a> with an assist for the only goal in the 1–0 victory over <a href="PFC%20Krylia%20Sovetov%20Samara">Krylia Sovetov Samara</a>. 
On 20 September 2020, he scored the only goal in the 1–0 victory over <a href="FC%20Ufa">Ufa</a>. Seven days later, he received two <a href="Yellow%20card%20%28association%20football%29">yellow cards</a> and was <a href="Red%20card%20%28association%20football%29">sent off</a> as Lokomotiv Moscow defeated CSKA 1–0. On 10 December, he scored his first European goal, as CSKA lost 3–1 to <a href="GNK%20Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo Zagreb</a> in the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a>. It was notably the first and only goal Dinamo conceded in the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Europa%20League%20group%20stage%23Group%20K">group stage</a>.
Loan to Kasımpaşa.
On 22 January 2021, he joined <a href="Kas%C4%B1mpa%C5%9Fa%20S.K.">Kasımpaşa</a> on loan until the end of the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20Kas%C4%B1mpa%C5%9Fa%20S.K.%20season">2020–21 season</a>. Kasımpaşa had an option to make transfer permanent at the end of the loan term.
Loan to Fatih Karagümrük.
On 12 January 2022, he joined <a href="Fatih%20Karag%C3%BCmr%C3%BCk%20S.K.">Fatih Karagümrük</a> on loan until the end of the <a href="2021%E2%80%9322%20Fatih%20Karag%C3%BCmr%C3%BCk%20S.K.%20season">2021–22 season</a>, with Fatih Karagümrük having an option to make transfer permanent at the end of the loan term.
International career.
Bistrović represented Croatia on youth levels. He was named in <a href="Nenad%20Gra%C4%8Dan">Nenad Gračan</a>'s <a href="2019%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship%20squads%23Croatia">23-man squad</a> for <a href="2019%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship">2019 UEFA Under-21 Euro</a>. However, he failed to make a single appearance as <a href="Croatia%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Croatia</a> finished last in their <a href="2019%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship%23Group%20C">group</a>. Two years later, he was again named in <a href="Igor%20Bi%C5%A1%C4%87an">Igor Bišćan</a>'s <a href="2021%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship%20squads%23Croatia">23-man squad</a> for the group stage of <a href="2021%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship">2021 UEFA Under-21 Euro</a>. He played all three group games as Croatia passed their <a href="2021%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship%23Group%20D">group</a> for the first time in history.
Honours.
